body:
That extra column is the index, which you clearly don't care about. Just use

``` python
frame.to_csv('experiment.csv', index=False)
```

Indexes are often important in pandas, so that's why the default is True.
Nobody here would bash you for having a question :) Especially about something as initially (perennially?) confusing as Indexes.

Tom,

I know that.  And if save it again, you will get another index.  And that
can and does mess up lots of code.  What I want is a saving format which
saves the index and column headings separately so when you save it and and
read it back you don't essentially get two indices but the original index
that the data frame had.  It's pretty simple and obvious really, even
though nobody seems to get it.  A dataframe is essentially a matrix with a
set of names for the rows and the columns.  The names should be saved
separately.

I guess I'll have to talk to Wes about it.

Best,

Dr. Greg St. George

On Wed, Mar 18, 2015 at 5:11 PM, Tom Augspurger notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Closed #9677 https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/9677.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/9677#event-258747049.

I guess maybe I didn't understand you're question then. Could you explain what you mean by saving the names separately?

Here's a successful round trip:

``` python
In [158]: df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [1, 2, 3], 'b': [1, 2, 3]})

In [159]: df
Out[159]: 
   a  b
0  1  1
1  2  2
2  3  3

In [160]: df.to_csv('test.csv')

In [161]: pd.read_csv('test.csv', index_col=0)
Out[161]: 
   a  b
0  1  1
1  2  2
2  3  3
```

Here's another one without the index:

``` python
In [162]: df.to_csv('test.csv', index=False)

In [163]: pd.read_csv('test.csv')
Out[163]: 
   a  b
0  1  1
1  2  2
2  3  3

In [164]: !cat test.csv
a,b
1,1
2,2
3,3
```

CSV is a text format, so it's almost impossible to guarantee complete fidelity when saving/loading data. There's no place to store extra metadata like whether the index was included or not.

We usually recommend HDF5 when someone is looking for a higher performance data than CSV, but the pandas flavor of HDF5 also is better at doing things like preserving data types and keeping track of whether something is an index or not. I would definitely recommend giving it a try:
http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/io.html#id2

I think I did just misread the original example. I'm pretty sure `pd.read_csv('experiment.csv', index_col=0)` is exactly what @GregStG is looking for. At least for the example given.

Once you get into more exotic stuff that you can't faithfully represent in text, you'll need to move to something like @shoyer suggested.

Stephen, Tom

Since a pandas DataFrame is an object with a index (row names) and a set of
column names, there should be a structure that saves those such that when
you save it, and then recall it, those two objects are the same.  I am just
saying that the structure you save should look like the structure you
have.  I have learned to work around this problem, but it is a problem with
pandas that this doesn't exist.  I have not investigated pandas internals
to know whether what I want is possible.  Maybe its very easy and you
essentially need a new name DataFrame_save for something that already
exists.

Anyway I am doing what I did not want to do, which is to argue about this.
I knew you would close this immediately and that is fine with me; I can
work around this problem with the stock data that I use.

Respectfully,

G.

> fidelity when saving/loading data. There's no place to store extra metadata
> like whether the index was included or not.
> 
> We usually recommend HDF5 when someone is looking for a higher performance
> data than CSV, but the pandas flavor of HDF5 also is better at doing things
> like preserving data types and keeping track of whether something is an
> index or not. I would definitely recommend giving it a try:
> http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/io.html#id2
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/9677#issuecomment-83268620.

@GregStG That's exactly what `to_hdf`/`read_hdf` does... or, for that matter, `to_pickle`/`read_pickle` (though I don't particularly recommend using pickle files). As I explained, a limitation of the CSV file format is that it can't faithfully represent pandas DataFrame objects.

Tom,

I haven't tried this, and I think you are right, because I don't think the
columns will ever be messed up.  Is the first column always the index? I do
the same thing by making all my data frames into time series, because I
always have a date column and I can pop that and assign it to the index.  I
haven't tried this, but if it always works, it should be flagged for the
next edition of Wes's book under 'saving dataframes'.

Greg

On Wed, Mar 18, 2015 at 8:24 PM, Tom Augspurger notifications@github.com
wrote:

> index_col=0) is exactly what @GregStG https://github.com/GregStG is
> looking for.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/9677#issuecomment-83268915.

> Is the first column always the index?

In a DataFrame the the index isn't really a "column". This is confusing and we're working on it.
Below, it's the dates to the left of the first column. (Again sorry if this is confusing).

With my same `df` as before

``` python
In [168]: df.index = pd.to_datetime(['2010-01-01', '2011-01-01', '2012-01-01'])
In [172]: df.to_csv('test.csv')

In [173]: pd.read_csv('test.csv', index_col=0, parse_dates=True)
Out[173]: 
            a  b
2010-01-01  1  1
2011-01-01  2  2
2012-01-01  3  3

In [174]: !cat test.csv
,a,b
2010-01-01,1,1
2011-01-01,2,2
2012-01-01,3,3
```

Hope that helps.

Stephen,

Haven't tried that.  Sounds like exactly what I want.  If so, then it is,
as I suspected, just my ignorance of something that is already there.  But
since I am working from the book, which focuses on the csv format, there is
just a need for a footnote or something.  But most people don't work from
books as exclusively as I do.

Greg

Greg

I have to admit, I have a copy of Wes's book on my desk at work but haven't read much of it :). This does seem like something worthy of a footnote, at least....
HDF5 has a section on pg. 169 (in my version).

Tom, Stephen

Yes it's there, and I probably skipped over it because I didn't know what
HDF5 was.  Maybe it's just because I am a mathematician, but structure
matters, and if you create a structure (in this case the DataFrame) there
should be a prominently flagged way to save it and recall it, named
save_dataframe and read_dataframe (or whatever) which allows you to do the
two most basic operations with that thing.  It should be right there when
you first introduce the structure (in this case, the DateFrame).  I have no
problem with this now, or for the last year, but it was a lot of problem
when I first started because the location of columns changes depending on
how many times you have saved your data set, which is not a good property,
and causes you to have to right lots of extra, rather ugly, code.

Thanks all,

Greg
